results.title: The True story of Lili Marlene
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit and Humphrey Jennings
results.brief_description: A dramatic reconstruction of the British counter-propaganda campaign against the popular German forces program from the Belgrade Radio. The theme song “Lili Marlene” introduced the German “Message from Home” session. The film shows how the Germans came to use the song, how the British captured it and how the BBC turned the song to our advantage during the African Desert campaign. The British Eighth Army adopted “Lili Marlene” as their own special marching song. Appearance by Marius Goring.

results.title: The True story of Eskimo Nell
results.creator_credit: Quest Films, Richard Franklin and Ron Baneth
results.brief_description: Two horny rogues on a road trip are out to find the illustrious lover (aka ‘womper’) from Alaska named Eskimo Nell. Dead Eye Dick (Max Gillies) and Mexico Pete (Serge Lazareff) travel around the Australian goldfields trying to bed women wherever they go. Dead Eye Dick is more talk than action as he has his heart set on finding Nell. Very much the storyteller, Dead Eye’s fanciful tales land the two in trouble and they often have to leave town in a hurry. Boobs and bawdiness abound in this ‘historical’ comedy drama from writers Alan Hopgood and Richard Franklin - also produced and directed by Franklin. Music by Brian May. Cast includes Abigail, Grahame Bond, Kris McQuade, Elli Maclure, Paul Vachon, Anthony Bazell, Ernie Bourne.

results.title: The True glory
results.creator_credit: Great Britain. Ministry of Information, United States. Office of War Information, Carol Reed and Garson Kanin
results.brief_description: A joint British-American documentary account of the allied invasion of Europe during World War II compiled from footage shot by nearly 1400 cameramen. Introduced by General Eisenhower it covers all the major events of the war in Europe from the Normandy landings to the fall of Berlin. Cast includes Dwight D. Eisenhower (as himself), Robert Harris (commentator) and Peter Ustinov (as himself). (Award: Best Documentary, Features 1946 Academy Awards)

results.title: The Trout
results.creator_credit: Maxwell Munden and Max Munden Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Anglers’ Corner”
In a fast-flowing, rocky river in Yorkshire, we watch the angler casting into the areas where he suspects the trout is lying. These northern rivers of Britain produce a meaner, more hungry trout, who needs less tempting than the southern variety. Three flies are used in the wet fly technique, placed about a yard apart on the line. With the aid of an underwater camera we see the trout being played and caught.

results.title: The Trout
results.creator_credit: Maxwell Munden and Max Munden Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Anglers’ Corner”
Trout in the southern regions of Britain live in the gently flowing chalk rivers, finding plenty of food in the weeds and insects, so they must be tempted with the dry fly. We watch the angler waiting for the trout to rise after flies drifting downstream, then casting into a river in Berkshire. Underwater photography shows the fish - and the strike!

results.title: The Troubled mind
results.brief_description: Through the eyes of a young nurse, dramatically introduced to a nursing vocation in mental hospitals, the film shows what life is like in a modern hospital dedicated to the treatment of the mentally sick.

results.title: The Trouble with women
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plant Supervisors Problems”.
Historically interesting film - to be taken in context to the year it was produced, ie the 1950’s! A supervisor, Brad, discusses his objections to a new woman worker with the Personnel Manager. He recalls trouble with previous women employees: one kept her desk like a dressing table and objected to moving to a different one; another engaged girl gave insufficient notice of leaving to marry; then there was absenteeism. The Personnel Manager suggests that it is up to Brad whether the new “girl” adds up to trouble. The audience is asked: “What is Brad’s trouble?” Useful for feminist theory studies.

results.title: The Trouble with medicine. [Part 2]
results.creator_credit: BBC, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Martin Freeth and Stefan Moore
results.brief_description: Last three episodes of a major and controversial international series which looks at the challenges that face medical science today. “Disordered states” (Dir: Peter Montagnon): Explores mental illness and how the treatment of patients differs in different countries. India, Italy and the United States are shown as examples. “Pandemic” (Dir: Susan Lambert, Stefan Moore): Looks at AIDS programs in the USA where the high-tech approach to medicine is out of reach of most of those who need it, in Thailand, where the entire population is at threat, and in Australia where there has been some success in containing the disease. “Life support” (Dir: Henry Singer) The final episode looks at how modern medicine deals with the frail, elderly and the dying, exploring issues such as when is enough life support enough? Warning - some scenes in this video may disturb some viewers.

results.title: The Trouble with medicine. [Part 1]
results.creator_credit: BBC, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Martin Freeth and Stefan Moore
results.brief_description: The first three episodes of a major and controversial international series which looks at the challenges that face medical science today. “Conceiving the future” (Dir: Tim Clark): Looks at genetics and the ethical dilemmas that arise from new technologies and being further able to pinpoint defects and abnormalities in unborn children. Asking questions such as what is abnormal? “Code of silence” (Dir: Stephen White): Examines to the heart of the doctor/patient relationship to find some extreme differences in the way physicians talk to their clients. “Temple of science” (Dir: Stefan Moore): Looks at the trend towards hi-tech medicine and specialisation, and Australia’s lead being the U.S.A. Warning: some scenes may be disturbing to some viewers.

results.title: The Trouble with Harry [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Alfred J Hitchcock Productions and Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: The trouble with Harry is that he’s dead, and while nobody else seems to mind, everybody thinks they are responsible for his death. After many burials and unearthings of the corpse, and a few blossoming romances between the major characters, the real cause of Harry’s death is revealed, and Harry troubles nobody again. “The Trouble with Harry” is a quirky comedy-mystery set in then autumnal splendour of New England. It is a decidedly different film from Hitchcock, in which Shirley Maclaine makes her screen debut. Includes music score by Bernard Herrmann. Cast includes Edmund Gwen, John Forsythe, Mildred Natwick and Jerry Mathers. Screenplay by John Michael Hayes, based on the novel by Jack Trevor Story. Cinematography by Robert Burks. Edited by Alma Macrorie. Music by Bernard Herrmann.
